# Conditional expectation developed from probability space

Let $(\Omega,\cal{F},P)$ be a probability space, where $Cond(\Omega) < \infty$, $\cal{F} = 2^{\Omega} = \text{ power set of } \Omega$, $\P(\{\omega\})> 0, \forall\omega \in \Omega$. Let $A \in \cal{F}$ such that $\P(A) \in (0,1)$. Thus we have 
$$
\E[X|A] = \sum_{\omega \in \Omega}X(\omega)\P(\{\omega\}|A),
$$
where
$$
\P(\{\omega\}| A) = \cases{\frac{\P(\{\omega\})}{\P(A)}, \omega \in A \\
0, \omega \notin A}
(\#eq:eq1)
$$

:::{.blackbox .brainstorm .center}
Why $$\P(\{\omega\}\cap A) = \P(\{\omega\})$$

Because there are only two options, either $\omega$ is in $A$ or it is not. Once $\omega \in A$, $\omega$ implies $A$.
:::

We can onw rewrite as follows
$$
\begin{align}
\E[X|A] &= \sum_{\omega \in A}X(\omega)\frac{\P(\{\omega\})}{\P(A)} \\
&= \frac{1}{\P(A)} \int_A XdP 
\end{align}
$$

:::{.blackbox .brainstorm .center}
We often write $$\int_AXdP = \sum X(\omega)\P(\{\omega\})$$
:::

We know that $\sigma-field$ is generated by $\cal{A} = \{\emp,\Omega,A,A^c\}$. If $B \in A$ with $\P(B) > 0,$ then
$$
\E[X|B] = \frac{1}{\P(B)}\int_BXdP
$$
